newsitem.title: INDIA: Indian rescue workers continue search for victims.
newsitem.headline: Indian rescue workers continue search for victims.

text.p: Rescue workers searched for more bodies from the wreckage of a bombed Indian train and officials said the army had launched a search operation for suspected tribal guerrillas.
Officials said more victims were expected from the wreckage but not as many as 300 initially believed killed. Almost 60 have been found since the blast on Monday.
"Rescue operations are still being carried out by the police," a police official in Guwahati, the capital of the northeastern state of Assam, told Reuters.
A senior army official told Reuters in Calcutta the army had cordoned off the site of the blast and was helping operations.
"We have started an offensive against the separatist rebels responsible for the blast," the army official, who did not want to be identified, told Reuters in Calcutta by telephone.

Three of the train's 19 coaches -- each crammed with up to 100 people leaving for the New Year holiday -- were destroyed in the blasts after the train left Kokrajhar station in Assam state for Delhi, police said.
There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack, which authorities blamed on Bodo tribal guerrillas who have waged a violent separatist struggle for nearly a decade.
The Bodos have demanded a separate tribal state north of the Brahmaputra river since the early 1980s. Their campaign took a violent turn at the end of the decade.
By Tuesday afternoon 59 bodies had been recovered at the site of the attack in the town of Sensapani, some 200 km (125 miles) west of Guwahati, authorities said.

Dozens of mutilated bodies, some of them children, lay on a soft rice paddy field near the tracks. Darkness and the remoteness of the region initially hampered rescuers and compounded confusion over the number of dead.
"It's all flesh and one can't distinguish bodies," the army official said.

President Shankar Dayal Sharma and Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda condemned the attack. The visiting Israeli President Ezer Weizman in a letter to Sharma said he was outraged by the bombing of the train.
Police said a remote-controlled device was used to blow up the Delhi-bound Brahmaputra Mail, an express train named after the sacred river that flows through India's north-east.
About 54 survivors lay huddled in a remote hospital in Alipurduar town in neighbouring West Bengal state.
"Most of the injuries were head injuries and fractures. All the local people volunteered to help and donated blood," Niyati Roy, a nurse at the hospital, said.
The injured were lying on dirty sheets. Cats roamed the hospital wards.
"This is a backward place in India. There are no specialist doctors. There is a shortage of equipment, insufficient staff and communications are bad," said Roy.
